{{Infobox book | name = Normal Accidents | image = Normal Accidents (Charles Perrow book) cover art.jpg | caption = | author = [[Charles Perrow]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = | language = | series = | subject = | genre = | publisher = Basic Books | pub_date = 1984 | english_pub_date = | media_type = | pages = | isbn = 978-0-691-00412-9 | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''Normal Accidents: Living with High-Risk Technologies''''' is a 1984 book by Yale sociologist [[Charles Perrow]], which provides a detailed analysis of complex systems from a sociological perspective. It was the first to "propose a framework for characterizing complex technological systems such as air traffic, marine traffic, chemical plants, dams, and especially [[nuclear power plant]]s according to their riskiness". Perrow argues that multiple and unexpected failures are built into society's complex and tightly coupled systems. Such accidents are unavoidable and cannot be designed around. Perrow's argument, based on systemic features and human error, is that big accidents tend to escalate, and technology is not the problem, the organizations are. Each of these principles is still relevant today.{{cite web |url=http://esd.mit.edu/WPS/wplit-2003-01.pdf |title=Normal Accidents by Charles Perrow |author=Daniel E Whitney |year=2003 |work=Massachusetts Institute of Technology }}{{Cite book|title=Meltdown: Why Our Systems Fail and What We Can Do About It|last=Clearfield|first=Chris|last2=Tilcsik|first2=András|publisher=Penguin Press|year=2018|isbn=9780735222632|location=New York|pages=}} ==System accidents== {{details|System accident}} "Normal" accidents, or system accidents, are so-called by Perrow because such accidents are inevitable in extremely complex systems. Given the characteristic of the system involved, multiple failures which interact with each other will occur, despite efforts to avoid them. Perrow said that [[operator error]] is a very common problem, many failures relate to organizations rather than technology, and big accidents almost always have very small beginnings.Perrow, Charles. ''Normal Accidents: Living with High-Risk Technologies'' New York: Basic Books, 1984. p.5 Such events appear trivial to begin with before unpredictably cascading through the system to create a large event with severe consequences.
''Normal Accidents'' contributed key concepts to a set of intellectual developments in the 1980s that revolutionized the conception of safety and risk. It made the case for examining technological failures as the product of highly interacting systems, and highlighted organizational and management factors as the main causes of failures. Technological disasters could no longer be ascribed to isolated equipment malfunction, operator error or acts of God.
Perrow identifies three conditions that make a system likely to be susceptible to Normal Accidents. These are: * The system is '''complex''' * The system is '''tightly coupled''' * The system has '''catastrophic potential''' ==Three Mile Island== The inspiration for Perrow's books was the 1979 [[Three Mile Island accident]], where a [[nuclear accident]] resulted from an unanticipated interaction of multiple failures in a complex system. The event was an example of a normal accident because it was "unexpected, incomprehensible, uncontrollable and unavoidable".Perrow, C. (1982), "The President’s Commission and the Normal Accident", in Sils, D., Wolf, C. and Shelanski, V. (Eds), ''Accident at Three Mile Island: The Human Dimensions'', Westview, Boulder, pp.173–184.
Perrow concluded that the failure at Three Mile Island was a consequence of the system's immense complexity. Such modern high-risk systems, he realized, were prone to failures however well they were managed. It was inevitable that they would eventually suffer what he termed a 'normal accident'. Therefore, he suggested, we might do better to contemplate a radical redesign, or if that was not possible, to abandon such technology entirely.{{cite web |title=In retrospect:Normal accidents |author=Nick Pidgeon |date=22 September 2011 Vol 477 |work=Nature }}
==New reactor designs== One disadvantage of any new nuclear reactor technology is that safety risks may be greater initially as reactor operators have little experience with the new design. Nuclear engineer [[David Lochbaum]] has explained that almost all serious nuclear accidents have occurred with what was at the time the most recent technology. He argues that "the problem with new reactors and accidents is twofold: scenarios arise that are impossible to plan for in simulations; and humans make mistakes". As one director of a U.S. research laboratory put it, "fabrication, construction, operation, and maintenance of new reactors will face a steep learning curve: advanced technologies will have a heightened risk of accidents and mistakes. The technology may be proven, but people are not".Benjamin K. Sovacool. ''A Critical Evaluation of Nuclear Power and Renewable Electricity in Asia, ''Journal of Contemporary Asia'', Vol. 40, No. 3, August 2010, p. 381. Sometimes, [[Redundancy (engineering)|engineering redundancies]] which are put in place to help ensure safety, may backfire and produce less, not more reliability. This may happen in three ways: First, redundant safety devices result in a more complex system, more prone to errors and accidents. Second, redundancy may lead to shirking of responsibility among workers. Third, redundancy may lead to increased production pressures, resulting in a system that operates at higher speeds, but less safely.{{cite web |url=http://iis-db.stanford.edu/pubs/20276/sagan_oe_dec03.pdf |title=Learning from Normal Accidents |author=Scott D. Sagan |date=March 2004 |work=Organization & Environment |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040714202943/http://iis-db.stanford.edu/pubs/20276/sagan_oe_dec03.pdf |archivedate=2004-07-14 |df= }} ==Readership== ''Normal Accidents'' is a very widely cited book, with more than 1,000 citations in the [[Social Science Citation Index]] and [[Science Citation Index]] to 2003. A German translation of the book was published in 1987 with a second edition in 1992.see data of the book in the German National Library http://d-nb.info/920805043 ==See also== *[[List of books about nuclear issues]] *''[[Three Mile Island: A Nuclear Crisis in Historical Perspective]]'' *[[Black Swan theory]] *''[[Megaprojects and Risk]]'' *[[Northeast Blackout of 2003]] *''[[Brittle Power]] *[[Fukushima nuclear disaster]]'' *[[International Nuclear Event Scale]] *''[[Small Is Beautiful]]'' *[[Space Shuttle Challenger disaster]] == Literature == * Charles., Perrow, (1984). ''Normal accidents : living with high-risk technologies,'' * Charles Perrow: ''Accidents, Normal'', in: [[International Encyclopedia of the Social & Behavioral Sciences]], Elsevier 2001, Pages 33–38, [[doi:10.1016/B0-08-043076-7/04509-5|online]] ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Accidents]] [[Category:Aviation safety]] [[Category:Systems engineering]] [[Category:Nuclear safety and security]] [[Category:Safety engineering]] [[Category:Failure]] [[Category:Three Mile Island accident]] [[Category:Books about nuclear issues]] [[Category:1984 books]] [[Category:Nuclear accidents and incidents]]

[[Image:Manuscript Thet Oera Linda Bok, pagina 48.jpg|thumb|280px|Page 48 of the Oera Linda manuscript]] The '''Oera Linda Book''' is a manuscript written in a form of [[Old Frisian]], purporting to cover historical, mythological, and religious themes of remote antiquity, from 2194 BCE to 803 CE. Among academics in [[Germanic philology]], the document is widely considered to be a [[hoax]] or [[forgery]].
The manuscript first came to public awareness in the 1860s. In 1872, Jan Gerhardus Ottema published a Dutch translation and defended it as genuine. Over the next few years there was a heated public controversy, but by 1879 it was universally accepted that the text was a recent composition. Nevertheless, a public controversy was revived in the context of 1930s [[Nazi occultism]], and the book is still occasionally brought up in esotericism and [[Atlantis]] literature. The manuscript's author is not known with certainty, hence it is unknown whether the intention was to produce a [[hoax]], a [[parody]] or simply an exercise in poetic fantasy.
Historian Goffe Jensma published a monograph on the manuscript in 2004, ''De gemaskerde god'' ("The Masked God"), including a new translation and a discussion of the history of its reception. Jensma concludes that it was probably intended as a "hoax to fool some nationalist [[Frisia|Frisians]] and orthodox Christians", as well as an "experiential exemplary exercise" by Dutch theologian and poet [[Piet Paaltjens|François Haverschmidt]].<ref>[http://historischhuis.nl/recensiebank/review/show/414] {{ISBN|90-6550-841-4}}</ref><ref>''Zeker ook nieuw aan mijn boek is wat ik op grond van het handschrift zelf kon concluderen over de tijd van ontstaan en over de wijze waarop het is gemaakt, namelijk in een aantal fases en niet door één auteur, maar zeker door twee en vermoedelijk door drie auteurs.'' [http://www.semafoor.net/Jensmareactie.htm]</ref>
==History of reception==
===19th century=== The Oera Linda Book, known in [[Old Frisian]] as ''Thet Oera Linda Bok'', came to light in 1867 when Cornelis Over de Linden (1811–1874) handed the manuscript, which he claimed to have inherited from his grandfather, via his aunt, over to Eelco Verwijs (1830–1880), the provincial librarian of Friesland, for translation and publication. Verwijs rejected the manuscript, but in 1872 Jan Gerhardus Ottema (1804–1879), a prominent member of the Frisian Society for History and Culture, published a Dutch translation. Ottema believed it to be written in authentic [[Old Frisian]]. The book was subsequently translated into English by William Sandbach in 1876, and published by Trübner & Co. of London.
Within the first few years after the appearance of the Oera Linda Book, its recent origin was established not only based on the exceptional claims being made, but also because of a number of anachronisms it contained. The text was nevertheless a source of inspiration for a number of occultists and speculative historians. While there was some debate among Dutch academics and in a number of newspapers about the book's authenticity during the 1870s, by 1879 it was widely recognized as a forgery.
===Nazi Germany=== More than forty years later, beginning in 1922, Dutch ''[[völkisch]]'' philologist [[Herman Wirth]] revived the issue. Wirth published a German translation of what he dubbed the "Nordic Bible" in 1933, as ''Die Ura Linda Chronik''.
A panel discussion on Wirth's book at the University of Berlin on 4 May 1934 was the immediate impulse for the foundation of the [[Ahnenerbe]] Nazi "[[think tank]]" by [[Heinrich Himmler|Himmler]] and Wirth, together with [[Richard Walther Darré]]. Because of the infatuation of Himmler with the Oera Linda Book and its consequent association with Nazi occultism, it became known as "Himmler's Bible". Wirth's book was by no means universally acclaimed among the Nazi-era Nordicist academics, and the 1934 panel discussion was steeped in heated controversy. [[Alfred Rosenberg]] and his circle rejected it. [[Gustav Neckel]] had praised Wirth's work before publication, but upon seeing its content published a dismayed recension.<ref>''Der Tag'', Berlin, 31. December 1933.</ref>
Speaking in defense of the book's authenticity were [[Walther Wüst]] and [[Otto Huth]], besides Wirth himself. Speaking against its authenticity were Neckel, Karl Hermann Jacob-Friesen (who identified it as a satirical hoax by Linden) and [[Arthur Hübner]]. Hübner was one of the most respected Germanists of his generation, and his verdict of the Oera Linda being a falsification settled the defeat of Wirth's party. The public defeat of Himmler's scholarly brand of "esoteric Nordicism" resulted in the foundation of Ahnenerbe, which attracted occultists such as [[Karl Maria Wiligut]] and was viewed with suspicion by the mainstream National Socialist ideologues of [[Amt Rosenberg]].<ref>Gerd Simon, [http://homepages.uni-tuebingen.de/gerd.simon/himmlerbibel.pdf Himmlers Bibel und die öffentlichkeitswirksamste Podiumsdiskussion in der Geschichte der Germanistik]</ref>
===Modern esotericism=== The book experienced a revival of popularity in the English-speaking world with the writings of Robert Scrutton. In ''The Other Atlantis'' (1977) he reproduced the full text of Sandbach's 1876 English translation, interspersed with his own commentaries on history and mythology.<ref>Scrutton, Robert. ''The Other Atlantis'' (1977) {{ISBN|0-72217-665-1}}</ref> In ''Secrets of Lost Atland'' (1979) he became the first to link the book with the concept of [[earth mysteries]], and, in particular, [[ley lines]] and [[telluric current|telluric energy]].<ref>Scrutton, Robert. ''Secrets of Lost Atland'' (1979) {{ISBN|0-72217-667-8}}</ref> Following Scrutton's example, English language accounts of the Oera Linda Book tend to place it within the [[New Age]] or [[alternate history]] genres, and do not associate it with National Socialism, as is the case in Germany.
Another figure to formulate a contemporary [[Modern Paganism|Neopagan]] tradition influenced by the Oera Linda Book was Tony Steele, who considered the book to reveal the genuine truth about the ancient European [[megalith|megalithic culture]]. In ''Water Witches'' (1998) he examined the book's use as a cultural identity marker by the Frisian-descended canal folk of the [[The Midlands|English Midlands]].<ref>Steele, Tony. ''Water Witches'' (1998) {{ISBN|1-86163-049-2}}</ref> In ''The Rites and Rituals of Traditional Witchcraft'' (2001) he connected the religious practices of the priestesses described in the book with later medieval [[witchcraft]] traditions.<ref>Steele, Tony. ''The Rites and Rituals of Traditional Witchcraft'' (2001) {{ISBN|1-86163-140-5}}</ref>
==Authorship== Among those who doubt the book's authenticity, the most popular candidates for the author of the manuscript are Cornelis Over de Linden or Eelco Verwijs. A recent third choice is the Protestant preacher François Haverschmidt (1835–1894), well known for writing poetry under the pseudonym Piet Paaltjens. Haverschmidt lived in Friesland and was an acquaintance of Verwijs.<ref>[http://skepsis.nl/oeralinda/ Skepsis.nl]</ref>
Goffe Jensma (2004) argued that Haverschmidt was the main writer of the book, with the help of Over de Linden and Verwijs. According to Jensma, Haverschmidt intended the Oera Linda Book as a parody of the [[Christianity|Christian]] [[Bible]]. An article in late 2007 by Jensma<ref>Extraordinary professor of Frisian Language and Culture, in particular the literary-historical aspects of Frisian, at the Faculty of Humanities of the [[Universiteit van Amsterdam]]</ref> says that the three authors of the translation intended it "to be a temporary hoax to fool some nationalist Frisians and orthodox Christians and as an experiential exemplary exercise in reading the Holy Bible in a non-fundamentalist, symbolical way."<ref>[http://www.rug.nl/news/2004/11/122_00?lang=en ''Oera Linda-boek was poging van Haverschmidt om bijbel te ontkrachten''] [[Rijks Universiteit Groningen]], 2004.</ref> Ignoring clues that it was a forgery, J. G. Ottema took it seriously, and it achieved popularity for the reasons given above. Its creators felt unable to admit that they had written it, and it became the foundation for new occult beliefs. Jensma concludes his article by saying "It is a perfect irony that a book written to unmask the Holy Bible as a book of human making was to become a bible itself."<ref name="Jensma">{{Citation|title=How to Deal with Holy Books in an Age of Emerging Science. The Oera Linda Book as a New Age Bible|journal=Fabula|date=November 2007|first=Goffe|last=Jensma|volume=48|issue=3–4|pages=229–249|doi=10.1515/FABL.2007.017|url=http://www.atypon-link.com/WDG/doi/abs/10.1515/FABL.2007.017|postscript=.}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Contents== Themes running through the Oera Linda Book include [[catastrophism]], [[nationalism]], [[matriarchy]], and [[mythology]]. The text alleges that Europe and other lands were, for a large part of their history, ruled by a succession of folk-mothers presiding over a hierarchical order of celibate priestesses dedicated to the goddess [[Frijjo|Frya]], daughter of the creator god Wr-alda and Jrtha, the earth mother. The claim is also made that this Frisian civilization possessed an alphabet that was the ancestor of the [[Greek alphabet|Greek]] and [[Phoenician alphabet]]s. Modern [[historiography]] is essentially ignored, particularly in the area of basic chronology of known events in the recent and distant past of Europe. Geological as well as geographical evidence that was readily available even as far back as Over de Linden's time is also mostly absent from the manuscript.
The earliest portion of the Oera Linda Book, namely ''Frya’s Tex'', was supposedly composed in 2194 BC, whereas the most recent part, the letter of Hidde Oera Linda, dates to AD 1256. Almost half of the entire book comprises ''The Book of Adela’s Followers'', the original text around which the rest grew. It is purported to have been compiled in the 6th century BC from a mixture of contemporary writings and ancient inscriptions. The last two sections of the Oera Linda Book contain a number of [[lacuna (manuscripts)|lacunae]] and the book itself breaks off in mid-sentence.
It also describes a lost land called [[Atlantis|Atland]] (the name given to Atlantis by the 17th century scholar [[Olof Rudbeck]]), which was supposedly submerged in 2194 BC, the same year as 19th century Dutch and Frisian almanacs, following traditional Biblical chronology given for [[Deluge (mythology)|Noah's flood]].<ref name="Jensma"/>
===Sections===
The Oera Linda Book is divided into six sections, further subdivided into a total of 53 chapters.
* Letters * The Book of Adela's Followers * The Writings of Adelbrost and Apollonia * The Writings of Frêthorik and Wiljow * The Writing of Konerêd * Fragments
==See also== *[[Old High German lullaby]], an Old High German lullaby mentioning Germanic deities that is also generally held to be a hoax *[[Kensington Runestone]], a runestone of supposedly Scandinavian origin found in USA, considered a hoax by archaeologists and historians *[[Germanic mythology]], the historical pre-Christian beliefs of the ancient Germanic peoples *[[Pseudohistory]] *[[Fakelore]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
* {{Citation |last=Jensma |first=Goffe |contribution=Het Oera Linda-boek. Wat er is en wat er mist| url=http://www.oeralindaboek.nl/index.php?m=dossiers&p=dossier17 | title=PBF. De Provinsjale Biblioteek fan Fryslân, 150 jaar geschiedenis in collecties |publisher=Tresoar |year=2002}} * Breuker, Ph.H. "It Friesch Genootschap, it Friesch Jierboeckjen en it Oera Linda Boek. De striid om taalbefoardering tusken 1827 en 1837", ''De Vrije Fries'' 60 (1980), 49–65. * {{Citation |last=Newbrook |first=Mark |title=Linguistic reconstruction and revisionist accounts of ancient history |journal=[[Australian Skeptics#The Skeptic|The Skeptic]] |issue=Winter |year=2000 |pages=42–47 |url=http://www.skeptics.com.au/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/theskeptic/2000/2.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120503085724/http://www.skeptics.com.au/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/theskeptic/2000/2.pdf |archivedate=3 May 2012 |df=dmy-all }} * Vinckers, Door J. Beckering "De onechtheid van het Oera Linda-Bôk, aangetoond uit de wartaal waarin het is geschreven.", Haarlem, Erven F. Bohn. 1876. [http://www.oeralindaboek.nl/pdf/OLBVinckers.pdf Oera Linda Boek] {{nl icon}}
==External links== * [http://www.rodinbook.nl/olbmanuscript.html Oera Linda Boek] Original manuscript (scanned facsimile) * [http://oeralinda.webs.com/ Oera Linda Book] Sandbach's 1876 English translation with Frisian text {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2010}}
{{Authority control}} [[Category:Pseudohistory]] [[Category:Books about Atlantis]] [[Category:Catastrophism]] [[Category:Esotericism]] [[Category:Frisian languages]] [[Category:Manuscripts]] [[Category:Hoaxes]] [[Category:1872 books]]

revision.comment: I made Kara Tointon into a hyperlink!!!
revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{Distinguish|The Sound of Music Live!}} '''''The Sound of Music Live''''' is a [[television special]] that was originally broadcast by [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] on 20 December 2015. The special was an adaptation of [[Rodgers and Hammerstein]]'s Broadway musical ''[[The Sound of Music]]'', starring [[Kara Tointon]] as [[Maria von Trapp]], performed and televised [[live television|live]] from [[3 Mills Studios]] in London.
On 9 November 2018, the production was broadcast in the United States as part of [[PBS]]'s performing arts anthology series ''[[Great Performances]]''.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.unionleader.com/great-performances-imports-uk-s-sound-of-music/article_f1a6feb2-4b7f-57f9-9a41-e05aa84a76de.html|title='Great Performances' imports UK's 'Sound of Music'|work=UnionLeader.com|access-date=2018-11-10|language=en}}</ref>
== Production == In October 2015, ITV announced that it would transmit a live adaptation of the musical ''[[The Sound of Music]]'' as part of its holiday programming lineup, in what would be the first time that such a programme had been attempted in the United Kingdom.<ref name="deadline-itvsom">{{cite web|title=ITV To Mount ‘The Sound Of Music Live!’ UK Christmas Special|url=http://deadline.com/2015/10/itv-sound-of-music-live-christmas-special-kara-tointon-1201590814/|website=Deadline.com|accessdate=2 February 2016}}</ref> ''The Sound of Music Live'' was part of ITV's continuing efforts to broadcast more live "[[Event television|event]]" programs, which are designed to attract critical masses of viewers by encouraging them to watch via the original broadcast, rather than via [[video on demand|catch-up]] services and [[digital video recorder]]s. The desire for increased ITV viewership came especially in the wake of declining ratings for its reality music competition ''[[The X Factor (UK)|The X Factor]]'', whose [[The X Factor (UK series 12)|series 12]] finale had the second-smallest viewership in the programme's history. ITV had similarly broadcast live episodes of its series ''[[Coronation Street]]'' in [[Coronation Street Live (2000 episode)|2000]] and [[Coronation Street Live (2010 episode)|2010]] in honour of its 40th and 50th anniversary respectively, and in 2015 for ITV's 60th anniversary.<ref name="deadline-itvsom"/>
This was not the first time that ''The Sound of Music'' had been adapted in such a manner. In 2013, U.S. network [[NBC]] broadcast its own [[The Sound of Music Live!|live television adaptation of ''The Sound of Music'']] starring [[country music|country]] singer [[Carrie Underwood]]; similarly to ITV's version, it was an adaptation of the original musical, and not based on the [[The Sound of Music|film version]]. Although it received mixed reviews, it was seen by over 18 million viewers. As follow-ups, NBC produced similar adaptations of ''[[Peter Pan Live!|Peter Pan]]'' and ''[[The Wiz Live!|The Wiz]]'' in 2014 and 2015 respectively.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newsday.com/entertainment/tv/the-wiz-live-nbc-s-latest-live-musical-broadcast-from-long-island-1.11164689|title=‘The Wiz Live!’: NBC’s latest live musical broadcast from Long Island|last1=Crook|first1=John|date=26 November 2015|website=newsday.com |publisher=Newsday|access-date=26 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://tvline.com/2013/12/06/sound-of-music-live-ratings-nbc/ |title=Ratings: NBC's Sound of Music Live! Does Something Very Good; Glee and Grey's Eye Lows |last=Mitovich|first=Matt Webb |date=December 6, 2013 |work=TVLine |accessdate=December 7, 2013}}</ref> Creative director [[Coky Giedroyc]] stated that ITV's iteration would be a "whole different animal" in comparison to NBC's, explaining that she wanted to "keep it true to the original", and maintain a focus on the political aspects of the story.<ref name="rt-differences">{{cite web|title=How will The Sound of Music Live work?|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/news/2015-12-20/how-will-the-sound-of-music-live-work|website=Radio Times|accessdate=2 February 2016}}</ref><ref name="guardian-future">{{cite web|last1=Martinson|first1=Jane|title=As ITV prepares for the Sound of Music Live, are we watching TV's future?| url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2015/dec/15/as-itv-prepares-for-the-sound-of-music-live-are-we-watching-tvs-future|website=The Guardian|accessdate=21 December 2015}}</ref> The production was conducted on soundstages at [[3 Mills Studios]] in London, with the sets alone having a budget of nearly £750,000.<ref name="rt-differences"/>
==Cast== [[Kara Tointon]] played Maria, and [[Julian Ovenden]] played Captain Georg von Trapp. The supporting cast included veterans of British television and theatre, including [[Alexander Armstrong]] as Max Detweiler, [[Katherine Kelly (actress)|Katherine Kelly]] as Baroness Elsa Schraeder, [[Maria Friedman]] as Mother Abess, [[Evelyn Hoskins]] as Liesl von Trapp, Jon Tarcy as Rolf Gruber, [[Mel Giedroyc]] as the housekeeper, Frau Schmidt, and [[Paul Copley]] as the butler, Franz.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Sound of Music Live!|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/episode/dwnsbw/the-sound-of-music-live|website=Radio Times|accessdate=21 December 2015}}</ref>
==Reception== ''The Sound of Music Live'' received mixed reviews. Mark Shenton of ''[[The Stage]]'' said it was a failed experiment, with "uninspired and sometimes insipid" choreography and direction, although he praised the cast's performances.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Shenton|first1=Mark|title=The Sound of Music Live review – ‘bold experiment doesn’t pay off’|url=https://www.thestage.co.uk/reviews/2015/the-sound-of-music-live-review-bold-experiment-doesnt-pay-off/|website=The Stage|accessdate=21 December 2015}}</ref> Claire Allfree of ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' said it lacked both the intimacy of live theatre and the scope of the big screen, but nevertheless judged it "more a success than it was a failure," saying that former ''[[EastEnders]]'' star Tointon "brought a refreshing earthiness and grit to Maria that made the passionate, unconventional novice feel thoroughly modern and accessible."<ref>{{cite web|title=The Sound of Music Live, review: 'much to enjoy'|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/tv-and-radio-reviews/12056862/the-sound-of-music-review-kara-tointon-live-itv.html|website=The Telegraph|accessdate=21 December 2015}}</ref> ''[[Daily Mirror|The Mirror]]'' said that Tointon was "showered with praise" for her performance.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kara Tointon shocks fans with incredible vocals as she plays Maria in The Sound Of Music live|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/tv/tv-news/kara-tointon-shocks-fans-incredible-7048037|website=The Mirror|accessdate=21 December 2015}}</ref>
The programme was watched by over 3.82 million viewers according to overnight ratings figures, being beaten by the [[The Apprentice (UK series eleven)|series eleven]] finale of ''[[The Apprentice (UK TV series)|The Apprentice]]'' (5.31 million) and its lead-in, the [[2015 BBC Sports Personality of the Year Award|BBC Sports Personality of the Year]] presentation (5.78 million).<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.digitalspy.com/tv/the-apprentice/news/a777848/uk-tv-ratings-the-apprentice-final-loses-800000-from-last-year-sports-personality-is-top-with-57m/ |title=UK TV ratings: The Apprentice final is lowest in 10 years, Sports Personality is top with 5.7m |author=Tom Eames |work=Digital Spy }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=ITV's The Sound of Music Live draws 4m viewers|url=https://www.thestage.co.uk/news/2015/itvs-the-sound-of-music-live-draws-4m-viewers/|website=The Stage|accessdate=21 December 2015}}</ref>
==See also== * [[2015 in British television]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
{{The Story of the Trapp Family Singers}}

revision.comment: Reverted [[WP:AGF|good faith]] edits by [[Special:Contributions/ZeR0101MiNt|ZeR0101MiNt]]: The "name" parameter is about the event name which is "Eurovision Dance Contest". Also, it is needed for the link to the 2008 article.
revision.text:
{{Infobox Song Contest |name = Eurovision Dance Contest |year=2009 |logo = |final = Postponed indefinitely{{cite web|url=http://esckaz.com/edc/|title=Eurovision Dance Contest has been put on hold|date=2010-01-19|publisher=''ESCKaz''|accessdate=2010-01-19}}{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovisiondance.tv/page/news?id=2913|title=3rd Eurovision Dance Contest postponed to 2010|publisher=EBU|accessdate=2009-05-28}} |presenters = |host = [[İctimai Television]] (İTV){{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=1879|title=Dance Contest 2009 to Baku, Azerbaijan}} |venue = [[Heydar Aliyev Sports and Exhibition Complex]], [[Baku]], [[Azerbaijan]] |vote = |debut = {{esc|Belarus|Dance}} |return = |withdraw = {{esc|Austria|Dance}}
{{esc|Finland|Dance}}
{{esc|Lithuania|Dance}}
{{esc|Netherlands|Dance}}
{{esc|Sweden|Dance}} }} [[File:Bedii Gimnastika 026.jpg|thumb|200px|[[Heydar Aliyev Sports and Exhibition Complex]], in Baku.]] The third [[Eurovision Dance Contest]] was originally planned to be organised in [[Baku]], [[Azerbaijan]] at the [[Heydar Aliyev Sports and Exhibition Complex]] on 26 September 2009.{{cite web|url=http://esckaz.com/edc/|title=European Broadcasting Union has finally officially confirmed the date of EDC 2009|date=2009-04-02|publisher=''ESCKaz''|accessdate=2009-04-02}} [[İctimai Televiziya və Radio Yayımları Şirkəti|İctimai Television]] was planning to increase the number of participating countries as well as inviting a world-famous star to host the contest, listing [[Jennifer Lopez]], [[Kylie Minogue]] and [[Shakira]] as candidates.{{cite web|url=http://en.apa.az/news.php?id=102659|title=We are negotiating with Jennifer Lopez, Kylie Minogue and Shakira to host the Eurovision Dance 2009 in Azerbaijan}} An additional extravaganza [[open-air concert]] was planned to be held, bringing together ex-participants of the [[Eurovision Song Contest|Eurovision]], [[Junior Eurovision Song Contest|Junior Eurovision]] and [[Eurovision Dance Contest|Eurovision Dance]] Contests on one stage.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovisiondance.tv/page/news?id=1905|title=Baku: More details announced at press conference}} ==Participants== On the date of cancellation, two countries had finished selection of the participating couples for the contest: *{{esc|Azerbaijan|Dance}} – host country *{{esc|Belarus|Dance}} – winners of 3-month long preselection show ''Star Dances'' were [[Yulia Raskina]] and [[Denis Moryasin]]. Producer of the show confirmed that they would take part in Eurovision Dance Contest 2010 if it is organised. *{{esc|Poland|Dance}} – [[Natasza Urbańska]] and Jan Kliment. *{{esc|Portugal|Dance}} – internal selection was expected to take place with the couple being selected from the RTP series ''Dança Comigo''.{{cite web|url=http://eurofire.blog.de/2009/04/15/news-splitter-5950321/|title=News Splitter (208)}} *{{esc|Russia|Dance}} – was set to be represented by professional couple [[Sergey Konovaltsev]] and [[Olga Konovaltseva]], named as participants of the show as early as in May 2008 and confirmed in 2009 edition of Russian version of ''[[Dancing with the Stars]]''. ==Cancellation== However, on 28 May 2009, [[European Broadcasting Union]] (EBU) had announced that the contest was postponed at least until Autumn 2010 as "the number of broadcasters that signed up for participation had not reach the desired level". According to a preliminary calculations, at least five countries that were taking part in [[Eurovision Dance Contest 2008]], namely {{esccnty|Austria|Dance}}, {{esccnty|Finland|Dance}}, {{esccnty|Lithuania|Dance}}, {{esccnty|Netherlands|Dance}} and {{esccnty|Sweden|Dance}} had announced withdrawal from the contest, with only {{esccnty|Belarus|Dance}} confirming its participation as a début country. According to contest coordinator on behalf of EBU Tal Barnea "concrete plans for a 2010 autumn event were being developed, with considerable changes to introduce a new programme proposal". These plans were expected to be unveiled in the autumn of 2009. EBU also praised "the commendable work on the next Eurovision Dance Contest already completed by our partners Ictimai Television and the Azerbaijani officials" stating that 2010 edition of the contest was planned to take place in [[Baku]], [[Azerbaijan]] as well. In January 2010, EBU Eurovision coordinator, [[Svante Stockselius]], announced that contest has been postponed again, and is now unlikely to happen at all, at least within the next couple of years. He explained this decision was the fact that the popularity of televised dance shows had calmed down recently. ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == *[http://www.eurovisiondance.tv/ Eurovision Dance Contest] *[http://www.esckaz.com/edc ESCKaz.com] {{Eurovision Dance Contest}} [[Category:Eurovision Dance Contest by year]] [[Category:2009 in Azerbaijan]] [[Category:2009 in Europe]] [[Category:Cancelled events]] [[Category:Events in Baku]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox concert | concert_name = This Is It | image = This Is It Michael Jackson banner.png | image_size = 220px | caption = | artist = [[Michael Jackson]] | type = | venue = | tour = | album = ''[[Michael Jackson's This Is It (album)|This Is It]]'' | start_date = July 13, 2009 | end_date = March 6, 2010 | number_of_legs = 2 | number_of_shows = 50 (cancelled) | duration = | support_act = | attendance = | gross = | website = {{URL|www.michaeljacksonlive.com|Official website}} | last_concert = [[Michael Jackson: Live at the Apollo 2002]]
(2002) | this_concert = '''This Is It'''
(2009–10) | Misc = }} '''This Is It''' was a planned [[concert residency]] by [[Michael Jackson]] which was scheduled to begin in July 2009 and end September 29, 2009 with a second leg which was scheduled to run from January 2010 through March 2010 with a total of 50 shows.https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/michael-jacksons-this-is-it-tour-balloons-to-50-show-run-stretching-into-2010-20090312 Jackson announced This Is It at a press conference in the [[The O2 Arena|O2 Arena]], stating that it would be his final series of concerts in London. [[AEG Live]], the concert promoters, released a promotional video that took up an entire commercial break, setting a record for [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]]. Initially, only 10 concerts were announced, but following public demand, 40 more concerts were added. Ticket sales broke several records and Jackson's album sales increased following the announcement; AEG Live estimated that the first 10 dates alone would have earned Jackson approximately £50 million. In preparation for the concert series, Jackson had been collaborating with high-profile figures including fashion designer [[Christian Audigier]], choreographer [[Kenny Ortega]] and bodybuilder [[Lou Ferrigno]]. Prior to Jackson's death in 2009, Allgood Entertainment sued Jackson for $40 million, claiming that he had breached an exclusivity agreement with them by agreeing to the This Is It concerts; the case was dismissed. After Jackson's death, AEG Live offered either refunds to ticket holders or a special "souvenir" ticket designed by Jackson. The cancelled shows, record-breaking ticket sales{{cite web |first=Daniel|last=Kreps |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/rockdaily/index.php/2009/03/12/michael-jacksons-this-is-it-tour-balloons-to-50-show-run-stretching-into-2010/ |title=Michael Jackson’s "This Is It!" Tour Balloons to 50-Show Run Stretching Into 2010 |publisher=''Rolling Stone'' |date=March 12, 2009 |accessdate=March 24, 2009 }}{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/7941221.stm |agency=BBC News |title= Michael Jackson announces comeback gigs |publisher= ''[[BBC]]''|date=March 13, 2009 |accessdate= November 5, 2009 |last=BBC staff }}{{cite web |url= http://www.livedaily.com/news/18434.html |author= The Livedaily Staff |work= [[LiveDaily]] |title= Michael Jackson breaking records with 50-show run in London |date= March 9, 2009 |accessdate= November 5, 2009 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100209062136/http://livedaily.com/news/18434.html |archivedate= February 9, 2010 |df= mdy-all }} and potential for a world tour{{cite web |url= http://au.news.yahoo.com/a/-/entertainment/6405947/australia-part-of-planned-jackson-tour/ |title= Australia part of planned world tour |publisher=[[Yahoo! 7]] |date= October 30, 2009 |accessdate= November 5, 2009 |last=Australia |first=Yahoo }}{{cite web |url= http://www.mtv.com/movies/news/articles/1624853/20091027/story.jhtml?rsspartner=rssColdFusion |author= The MTV Staff |work= MTV |title= This Is It Director Kenny Ortega On Michael Jackson's Final Rehearsals |date= November 5, 2009 |accessdate= September 23, 2009}} led to This Is It being termed "the greatest concert[s] that never happened."{{cite web |first=IGN |last=Staff |url=http://movies.ign.com/articles/101/1016381p1.html|title=Michael Jackson’s "This Is It!" Tour Balloons to 50-Show Run Stretching Into 2010 |publisher=''IGN'' |date=August 20, 2009 |accessdate=November 5, 2009}}{{cite web |url=http://www.michaeljackson.com/ru/this-is-it|title=''Jackson's This Is It This Fall'' | publisher=[[Sony]] |date=August 20, 2009 |accessdate=November 5, 2009|first=Sony |last=Staff}} [[Columbia Pictures]] acquired the footage of the rehearsals and released a [[concert film]], ''[[Michael Jackson's This Is It]],'' accompanied by a [[Michael Jackson's This Is It (album)|compilation album of the same name]]. ==Promotion and significance== {{Wikinews|Michael Jackson to make last public concerts}} Jackson announced the first 10 performances during a press conference at the O2 Arena on March 5, 2009. As many as 7,000 fans and 350 reporters awaited Jackon's arrival, many donning Jackson-related clothing.{{cite web |url=http://www.mtv.co.uk/artists/michael-jackson/news/100481-jackson-set-to-announce-shows|title=Jackson set to announce shows|publisher=MTV|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=March 5, 2009}} {{cite news |last= Akbar |first=Arifa |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/news/jacko-on-tour-this-will-be-the-final-curtain-call-i-love-you-i-love-you-all-1638497.html|title=Jacko on tour: 'This will be the final curtain call. I love you, I love you all' – News, Music |publisher=''[[The Independent]]''|date=March 6, 2009|accessdate=March 6, 2009 | location=London}} He commented at the conference, "I just wanted to say that these will be my final show performances in London. When I say this is it, it really means this is it", adding that it was his "final curtain call", although he may have just been referring to performing in London. Organizers touted the residency as, "dramatic shows [that] promise an explosive return with a band of the highest calibre, a state-of-the-art stage show and incredible surprise [[support act]]s".{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/celebritynews/4944927/Michael-Jackson-announces-comeback-gigs.html |title=Michael Jackson announces comeback gigs |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''|date=March 6, 2009|accessdate=March 6, 2009 |last= Khan|first=Urmee | location=London}} Hours before the press conference, promotional posters for the residency were displayed around London. Further promotion took up an entire [[commercial break]] period on [[ITV London]] during ''[[Dancing on Ice (Series 4)|Dancing on Ice]]'', the first time this has ever happened for a musical artist. The advert, which cost £1 million to air, was viewed by 11 million people. {{cite web |last=Griffin|first=Zoe |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/celebs/news/2009/03/04/michael-jackson-has-50-medical-tests-to-prove-he-can-manage-02-arena-dates-115875-21171604/|title=Michael Jackson has 50 medical tests to prove he can manage 02 Arena dates |publisher=''[[Daily Mirror]]''|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=March 5, 2009}} {{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/7925388.stm|title= 'Final curtain call' for Jackson|publisher=BBC|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=March 6, 2009|last=Youngs |first=Ian }} {{cite web|url=http://www.mediaweek.co.uk/News/MostEmailed/888126/Michael-Jackson-takes-entire-three-half-minute-ITV-ad-slot/ |title=Michael Jackson takes entire three and a half minute ITV ad slot |publisher=www.mediaweek.co.uk|date=March 6, 2009|accessdate=March 6, 2009|last=Barnett|first=Emma }}{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/celebs/news/2009/03/09/michael-jackson-live-dates-ad-during-dancing-on-ice-seen-by-11m-fans-115875-21184002/|title=Michael Jackson live dates ad during Dancing On Ice seen by 11m fans|publisher=''Daily Mirror''|date=March 9, 2009|accessdate=March 9, 2009}} The shows, Jackson's first significant concert events since the [[Michael Jackson: 30th Anniversary Celebration]] in 2001, had been cited as one of the year's most important musical events,{{cite news|first=Rosie|last=Swash|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2009/mar/05/michael-jackson-o2-arena|title=Michael Jackson can't fail to sell out the O2 arena|publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=March 5, 2009 | location=London}} and as the greatest comeback in the history of pop.{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1151504/Michael-Jackson-chooses-Londons-O2-arena-greatest-comeback-history.html|author=Simon Cable |work=[[Dailymail.co.uk]] |title=Michael Jackson chooses London's O2 arena for the 'greatest comeback in history'|date=November 5, 2009 |accessdate=February 21, 2009}}{{cite web |url=http://www.nme.com/news/michael-jackson/43249|title=Michael Jackson announces O2 Arena London gigs — and retirement?|publisher=''[[NME]]''|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=March 5, 2009}} Randy Phillips, president and chief executive of [[AEG Live]], stated that the first 10 dates would earn Jackson approximately £50 million (about US$80.1 million).{{cite news|first=Patrick |last= Foster |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article5854735.ece|title=Michael Jackson grand finale curtain-raiser|publisher=''[[The Times]]''|date=March 6, 2009|accessdate=March 5, 2009 | location=London}} ''[[The Guardian]]'' characterized the concerts as an "astonishing comeback for a man who in recent years has been dogged by controversy", adding that Jackson still had "enormous commercial clout". The ''[[Evening Standard]]'' stated that the deal was the "showbiz coup of the decade" for AEG Live, while ''[[The Independent]]'' remarked that the finalized 50 concerts would provide London with a "much-needed" economic boost.{{cite web |first=Amar |last=Singh |url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23661911-details/Detoxing+brand+Jacko/article.do |title=Detoxing Brand Jacko |publisher=''[[Evening Standard]]'' |date=March 13, 2009 |accessdate=March 24, 2009 }}{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/features/the-barometer-michael-jackson-angela-gheorghiu-horne-and-corden-madonna-in-fancy-dress-1649091.html |title=The Barometer: Michael Jackson; Angela Gheorghiu; Horne and Corden; Madonna in fancy dress |publisher=''The Independent'' |date=March 20, 2009 |accessdate=March 25, 2009 | location=London}} Joe Cohen, chief executive of [[Seatwave]], told [[BBC 6 Music]] that the shows would generate £1 billion for the economy.{{cite web |url=http://www.metro.co.uk/metrolife/music/article.html?Michael_Jackson_in_billion_pound_boost_to_economy&in_article_id=652877&in_page_id=25 |title=Michael Jackson in 'billion pound' boost to economy |publisher=''[[Metro (Associated Metro Limited)|Metro]]'' |date=May 8, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }} ==Public interest== [[File:O2 with Canary Wharf and City of London (15007282651).jpg|right|thumb|250px|The O2 Arena, where the concerts would have been held]] Some websites offered early tickets, which the [[Association of Secondary Ticket Agents]] warned were fake. "We are warning people not to buy tickets that are not yet on sale because it is unlikely that they will receive those tickets", announced the organization's chief, Graham Burns. He concluded, "It's impossible when the dates haven't been announced to be selling tickets for something when there are no announced dates".{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/news/michael-jackson/43235|title=Michael Jackson London 02 Arena ticket warning issued|publisher=''NME''|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=March 5, 2009}} Jackson's official website allowed fans to register early for a "pre-sale" draw. Some fans had difficulty applying, as the website could not deal with the large number of registrations—reportedly up to 16,000 applications a second.{{cite news |first=Matthew|last=Moore|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/celebritynews/4945911/Michael-Jackson-O2-ticket-website-attracting-16000-visits-a-second.html|title=Michael Jackson O2 ticket website attracting 16,000 visits a second |publisher=''The Daily Telegraph'' |date=March 6, 2009|accessdate=March 6, 2009 | location=London}} In the space of 24 hours, nearly a million people from around the world registered for pre-sale tickets, enough to fill the venue 50 times over.{{cite web |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/celebs/news/2009/03/06/michael-jackson-adds-10-more-dates-to-comeback-tour-115875-21177334/|title=Michael Jackson adds 10 more dates to comeback tour |publisher=''Daily Mirror'' |date=March 6, 2009|accessdate=March 6, 2009}}{{cite web |url=http://www.mtv.co.uk/artists/michael-jackson/news/102275-michael-jackson-announces-dates |title=Michael Jackson Announces Dates |publisher=MTV |date=March 10, 2009 |accessdate=March 29, 2009 }} Tickets that had not even been printed were selling on auction website [[eBay]] for £300.{{cite news|first=Elizabeth |last=Day |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/mar/08/michael-jackson-profile-pop-culture |title=Off the wall but still invincible |publisher=''The Guardian'' |date=March 8, 2009|accessdate=March 8, 2009 | location=London}} Sales of Jackson's albums increased following the press conference. Overnight, sales of ''[[Off the Wall]]'' rose 200%, ''[[Bad (album)|Bad]]'' rose 110%, ''[[Dangerous (Michael Jackson album)|Dangerous]]'' rose 165% and ''[[Thriller 25]]'' rose 155%.* {{cite web |url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/showbiz/music/article2302221.ece |title=Jacko's album sales are backo|date=March 7, 2009 |publisher=[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090310080317/http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/showbiz/music/article2302221.ece |archive-date=March 10, 2009 |dead-url=yes}} The two-day pre-sale began on March 11, and 40 extra dates were added to meet high demand—five of these dates were reserved in their entirety for the public sale. More than 1.5  million fans caused two sites offering pre-sale tickets to crash within minutes of going online.{{cite web |url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/showbiz/article-23660868-details/1.5m+fans+crash+sites+in+rush+for+Jacko+gig/article.do |title=1.5m fans crash sites in rush for Jacko gig |publisher=''Evening Standard'' |date=March 11, 2009 |accessdate=March 30, 2009 }} In the space of two hours, 190,000 tickets were sold.{{cite news |first=Simon |last=Cable |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1161160/Fans-fury-touts-sell-Michael-Jackson-concert-tickets-16-000-pair-black-market.html |title=Fans' fury as touts sell Michael Jackson concert tickets for up to £16,000 a pair on black market |publisher=''Daily Mail'' |date=March 13, 2009 |accessdate=March 30, 2009 | location=London}} Two million people tried to buy pre-sale tickets in the space of 18 hours.{{cite news |first=David |last=Miranda |url=http://www.news.com.au/heraldsun/story/0,21985,25175199-5006024,00.html |title=Michael Jackson doubles London shows after 2 million seek tickets |publisher=''[[Herald Sun]]'' |date=March 12, 2009 |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} Veronica Schmidt of ''[[The Times]]'' stated of the reception, "Michael Jackson has floored his critics",{{cite news |first=Veronica |last=Schmidt |url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/music/article5889522.ece |title=Michael Jackson sells out London concerts and adds more shows |publisher=''The Times'' |date=March 11, 2009 |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} while organizers proclaimed it a "cultural phenomenon".{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7940515.stm |title=Jackson to play 50 gigs at the O2 |publisher=BBC |date=March 12, 2009 |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} It was announced that Jackson would break the record for number of shows performed by an artist at a single venue, which had been set by [[Prince (musician)|Prince]], who hosted a residency at the same arena for his [[21 Nights in London: The Earth Tour]] concerts. According to Jackson's website, the following records were or would have been broken: "The biggest audience ever to see an artist in one city", "The greatest number of people to attend a series of arena shows", "The fastest ticket sales in history". Randy Phillips acknowledged that Jackson could have sold out even more dates, but this would have conflicted with other career plans.{{cite web |first=Ray |last=Waddell |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/269213/update-michael-jackson-up-to-50-london-shows |title=Update: Michael Jackson Up To 50 London Shows |publisher=''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' |date=March 12, 2009 |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} On March 13, the other 50% of seats for dates 1–45 and all the seats for dates 46–50 went on sale to the general public. Within four hours, all 50 dates had sold out.* {{cite web |url=https://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/Showbiz-News/Michael-Jackson-This-Is-It-Shows-At-O2-Sell-Out-After-Tickets-Go-On-General-Sale/Article/200903215240762?lpos=Showbiz_News_First_Home_Article_Teaser_Region_1&lid=ARTICLE_15240762_Michael_Jackson_This_Is_It_Shows_At_O2_Sell_Out_After_Tickets_Go_On_General_Sale |title=Jackson's Tears Of Joy As O2 Shows Sell Out |date=March 13, 2009 |publisher=[[Sky News]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090316004206/https://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/Showbiz-News/Michael-Jackson-This-Is-It-Shows-At-O2-Sell-Out-After-Tickets-Go-On-General-Sale/Article/200903215240762?lpos=Showbiz_News_First_Home_Article_Teaser_Region_1&lid=ARTICLE_15240762_Michael_Jackson_This_Is_It_Shows_At_O2_Sell_Out_After_Tickets_Go_On_General_Sale |archive-date=March 16, 2009 |dead-url=yes}}} At this stage, the sales of ''[[King of Pop (album)|King of Pop]]'' were up 400% and the sales of ''[[Thriller (Michael Jackson album)|Thriller]]'' were up 200%.{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/SHOWBIZ/Music/03/13/michael.jackson.concerts.tickets/ |title=750,000 tickets for Jackson concerts sell in 4 hours |publisher=CNN |date=March 13, 2009 |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} Tickets appeared on eBay for as much as £10,000.{{cite news |first=Rosie |last=Swash |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/mar/13/michael-jackson-o2-arena-residency-sells-out |title=Michael Jackson's 50 dates at London's O2 arena sell out |publisher=''The Guardian'' |date=March 13, 2009 |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} ==Preparation and concert details== The 50-concert run was originally scheduled to start on July 8, 2009 and conclude on February 24, 2010.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/8060282.stm |title=Jackson delays opening tour dates |publisher=BBC |date=May 20, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }} Each of the shows would have been performed at the O2 Arena in London, which has a capacity of 23,000.{{cite web|first=Andre|last=Paine|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/269278/michael-jackson-says-london-concerts-to-be-final-curtain-call|title=Michael Jackson Says London Concerts To Be 'Final Curtain Call'|publisher=''Billboard''|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=March 5, 2009}} New York-based fashion designer [[Zaldy]] served as head costumer, creating ten of Jackson's stage looks while the other six were created by his longtime costumers, Michael Bush and Dennis Tompkins. Jay Ruckel from La Crasia Gloves recreated Jackson's iconic single glove for the concerts.{{cite news |first=William |last=Sherman |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/money/2009/06/14/2009-06-14_theyre_still_proudly_making_it_in_nyc_manufacturing_alive__well_at_feisty_factor.html |title=Michael Jackson, Hubble Telescope draw from New York manufacturing |publisher=''[[New York Daily News]]'' |date=June 14, 2009|accessdate=June 20, 2009}} The costumes he was to wear during the shows were encrusted with 300,000 [[Swarovski crystals]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/news/michael-jackson/45530|title=Extra Michael Jackson O2 Arena tickets made available|date=June 23, 2009|publisher=NME|accessdate=June 26, 2009}} In April 2009, thousands of dancers flew in from all around the world to audition from the 13th to the 15th for Jackson, who helped select the 11 finalists in person.{{cite web |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/268649/michael-jackson-rehearsals-move-forward |title=Michael Jackson Rehearsals Move Forward |publisher=Billboard |date=May 12, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }} [[Kenny Ortega]], who had collaborated with Jackson previously, was to work on the overall design and direction of concerts. Ortega said that the final product would have been a "theatrical musical experience".{{cite web |url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/Showbiz-News/Michael-Jackson-Auditions-Dancers-For-Tour-And-Works-With-Director/Article/200905215280285 |title=Michael Jackson Gets Ready For Tour |publisher=Sky News |date=May 12, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.nme.com/news/michael-jackson/44599 |title=Michael Jackson enlists 'High School Musical' director for London O2 shows |publisher=''NME'' |date=May 12, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }}{{cite web |url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/Showbiz-News/Michael-Jacksons-Comeback-Tour-12-Dancers-Picked-To-Join-Singer-On-Stage-At-Londons-O2-Aena/Article/200905315284334 |title=This Is It: Jacko Picks Comeback Gig Dancers |publisher=Sky News |date=May 19, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }} According to Randy Philips, £13 million was to be spent on producing the concerts, which would have included 18–22 songs and 22 different sets. There also would have been [[Aerial dance|aerial dancing]] similar to routines by [[Cirque du Soleil]]. Carla Ferrigno told [[Reuters]] that [[Lou Ferrigno|her husband Lou]] had been helping Jackson train in advance of the shows. Jackson and Ferrigno had previously worked together.{{cite news |first=Alex |last=Dobuzinskis |url=http://blogs.reuters.com/fanfare/2009/06/19/the-hulk-trains-michael-jackson-ahead-of-london-concerts/ |title=The Hulk trains Michael Jackson ahead of London concerts |publisher=Reuters |date=June 19, 2009 |accessdate=June 19, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090621224923/http://blogs.reuters.com/fanfare/2009/06/19/the-hulk-trains-michael-jackson-ahead-of-london-concerts/ |archivedate=June 21, 2009 |df=mdy-all }} On May 20, it was announced that the first concert would be pushed back five days to July 13 and three other July dates would be rescheduled for March 2010. AEG Live said that the delay was necessary because more time was needed for dress rehearsals. The revised schedule called for 27 shows between July 13 and September 29, 2009, followed by a three-month break, before resuming in the new year with 23 more shows between January 7 and March 6, 2010. Some fans petitioned for the reversal of AEG Live's decision.{{cite web |url=http://www.nme.com/news/michael-jackson/44820 |title=Michael Jackson fans launch petition over O2 Arena postponement |publisher=''NME'' |date=May 21, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }} In late June, several hundred seats for each of the dates were put on sale. These seats were held back until production logistics were worked out.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/8115638.stm |title=More Jackson tickets up for sale |publisher=BBC |date=June 23, 2009 |accessdate=June 25, 2009 }} It was suggested that after the London concerts, Jackson might head to [[Australia]], [[Europe]], [[India]], [[China]], [[Hong Kong]] and [[Japan]] before moving on to North America. Randy Phillips, the CEO of [[AEG Live]], told The LA Times that Australia was part of Michael Jackson's international tour plans.{{cite web |url=http://www.take40.com/news/16590/michael-jackson-planning-australian-tour-before-his-death |title=Michael Jackson Planning Australian Tour Before His Death |publisher=Take 40 |date=June 28, 2009 |accessdate=May 6, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140504000236/http://www.take40.com/news/16590/michael-jackson-planning-australian-tour-before-his-death |archivedate=May 4, 2014 |df=mdy-all }} According to Jermaine Jackson's 2011 book ''You Are Not Alone: Michael Through a Brother's Eyes'', after the London concerts were finished, Jackson was planning to extend his deal with AEG Live which included new music, a potential three-picture movie deal, a series of one-off concert dates starting in China, a halftime slot at one of the future [[Super Bowl]] games to surpass his own halftime show at the [[Super Bowl XXVII]] in January 1993 and two more tours (one of which was to be a final reunion with his brothers based on a promise made to their [[Katherine Jackson|mother]] to see her sons perform together one last time before she passed away). After the deal was completed, he planned to take time off from musical entertainment and move on to (possibly) directing his own film ideas, such as making a feature-length motion picture based on his 1982 song "Thriller" and [[Michael Jackson's Thriller (music video)|the music video of the same name]]. It was also later revealed that [http://www.damienshields.com/michael-jacksons-halloween-special-that-never-was/ a yearly Halloween television special] based on his horror-themed songs, such as "Thriller" and "Ghosts", was part of Jackson's deal with AEG Live. In [[Trial of Conrad Murray|Conrad Murray's manslaughter trial]], David Walgren stated another one of Jackson's future plans was to open a children's hospital. This was heard in an audio tape Conrad Murray played of Jackson under the influence of propofol on May 10, 2009. His voice is barely recognisable in the recording, but he can be clearly heard saying that he wanted to build the greatest children's hospital in the world and name it after himself: The ''Michael Jackson's Children's Hospital''. Walgren also stated that while the tour was happening, Jackson wanted to buy an estate with streams, horses and animals so his three children, Prince, Paris and Blanket could live normal lives as their father performed the concerts, as he was photographed looking for a house in the United Kingdom with his children. Walgren also said that the tour would begin that summer, and Jackson could take his children out of school and bring them with him so they could see him perform in London. ===Songs prepared=== As shown in ''[[Michael Jackson's This Is It]]'', songs prepared for the concerts included "[[Wanna Be Startin' Somethin']]", "[[Jam (song)|Jam]]", "[[They Don't Care About Us]]", "[[Human Nature (Michael Jackson song)|Human Nature]]", "[[Smooth Criminal]]", "[[The Way You Make Me Feel]]", a medley of songs by [[The Jackson 5]] consisting of "[[I Want You Back]]", "[[The Love You Save]]", "[[I'll Be There (The Jackson 5 song)|I'll Be There]]" and "[[Shake Your Body (Down to the Ground)]]", "[[I Just Can't Stop Loving You]]", "[[Thriller (song)|Thriller]]", "[[Beat It]]", "[[Black or White]]", "[[Earth Song]]", "[[Billie Jean]]", and "[[Man in the Mirror]]". Later on, "[[Stranger in Moscow]]", "[[You Are Not Alone]]", "[[Don't Stop 'Til You Get Enough]]", "[[Rock with You (Michael Jackson song)|Rock with You]]", "[[Dirty Diana]]" ,"[[You Rock My World]]", "[[Dangerous (Michael Jackson song)|Dangerous]]", "[[We Are the World]]", "[[Heal the World]]" and "[[Will You Be There]]" were also confirmed to have been planned for the shows. Due to the larger than usual roster of songs, as well as time constraints, Jackson would perform some songs with one verse less than he did in previous tours (such as "Wanna Be Startin' Somethin'", "Jam", "The Way You Make Me Feel" and "Black or White"). "[[Bad (Michael Jackson song)|Bad]]" was rumored to have been reserved for select concerts. On the final dates, Jackson wanted to perform a ballad called "River Ripple", written by him, with an African choir and his children. During the final concert before "Man in the Mirror", Michael was slated to premiere a song called "Best of Joy", written and recorded in 2009 prior to Jackson's death. As of 2018, the full version of "River Ripple" remains unreleased (although snippets of the song have leaked on YouTube), while "Best of Joy" was officially released in 2010 on Jackson's first posthumous album of unreleased songs, ''[[Michael (album)|Michael]]''. ==Dates== {|class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" ! style="width:130px;"| Date ! style="width:130px;"| City ! style="width:160px;"| Country ! style="width:180px;"| Venue |- |- style="background:#ddd;" |colspan="4"|'''First Leg''' |- |July 13, 2009 |rowspan="27"|[[London]] |rowspan="27"|[[United Kingdom]] 3, 2009 |- |August 10, 2009 |- |August 12, 2009 |- |August 17, 2009 |- |August 19, 2009 |- |August 24, 2009 |- |August 26, 2009 |- |August 28, 2009 |- |August 30, 2009 |- |September 1, 2009 |-
