8, 2010 |- |February 10, 2010 |- |February 12, 2010 |- |February 16, 2010 |- |February 18, 2010 |- |February 20, 2010 |- |February 22, 2010 |- |February 24, 2010 |- |March 1, 2010 |- |March 3, 2010 |- |March 6, 2010 |- |} ==Personnel== {{col-begin}} {{col-3}} ;Musicians *[[Michael Jackson]] – [[Lead vocalist|vocals]], [[Artistic director (music)|show direction]], [[choreographer]] *[[Orianthi|Orianthi Panagaris]] – [[guitar]] *[[Tommy Organ]] – guitar *Alex Al – [[Bass guitar|bass]] *[[Jonathan Moffett]] – [[Drum kit|drums]] *Michael Bearden – [[Keyboard instrument|keyboard]]s, [[musical director]] *[[Morris Pleasure]] – keyboards *Bashiri Johnson – [[Percussion instrument|percussion]] *Dorian Holley – [[Backing vocalist|vocals]], vocal direction *[[Judith Hill]] – vocals *Darryl Phinnessee – vocals *Ken Stacey – vocals {{col-3}} ;Dancers *Michael Jackson *Daniel Yao{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wwkPZf4zRmk|title=This Is It dancers on the Ellen Show|year=2009|publisher=YouTube}} *Nicholas Basir *[[Daniel Celebre]] (a.k.a. Da FunkyMystic) *[[Mekia Cox]] *Chris Grant (a.k.a. Kriyss Grant) *[[Misha Gabriel]] *Shannon Holtzapffel *Devin Jamieson *[[Charles Klapow]] *[[Dres Reid|Ricardo Reid]] (aka Dres Reid) *Danielle Rueda Watts *Tyne Stecklein *Timor Steffens (a.k.a. Timor Dance) {{col-3}} ;Production and other personnel *[[Kenny Ortega]] – show direction *Alif Sankey – [[Assistant producer|associate production]] *Michael Cotten – [[Production designer|production design]] *Michael Curry – production design *Michael Jackson & [[Travis Payne]] – [[choreography]] *Stacy Walker – choreography assistance *Tony Testa – choreography assistance *Patrick Woodroffe – [[Lighting designer|lighting design]] *[[David Elsewhere]] – dance coaching *Shahzad Perez - Specialty Act *Gregg Smith – [[Casting (performing arts)|casting direction]] *Karen Faye Heinze – hair and make-up *[[Zaldy Goco]] – [[Costume designer|chief of costume design]] *Michael Bush – [[Costume designer|costume design]] *Dennis Thompkins - [[Costume designer|costume design]] *[[AEG Live]] – [[Promoter (entertainment)|promotion]] *Dave Polich - synth programming {{col-end}} ==Litigation== In June 2009, concert promoter Allgood Entertainment, represented by Ira Meyerowitz and Jon Kekielek of MJlawfirm, sued Jackson for $40 million. He claimed that Jackson, through his manager [[Frank DiLeo]], had agreed to a single and a $30 million reunion concert with [[The Jackson 5]] and his sister [[Janet Jackson]]. According to the concert promoter, the alleged contractual agreement prevented Jackson from performing elsewhere before the reunion concert and for a three-month period after it. Thus, agreeing to a 50 date residency at the O2 arena was an alleged breach of the Allgood Entertainment contract. The filing company stated that AEG Live knew of the alleged agreement with Jackson and used their dominance in the industry to coerce Jackson into agreeing to the residency.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/8094537.stm |title=Jackson sued over reunion concert |publisher=BBC |date=June 11, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }}{{cite news |first=Sean |last=Michaels |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/jun/12/michael-jackson-sued-o2-arena|title=Michael Jackson sued for O2 arena residency|publisher=''The Guardian'' |date=June 12, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 | location=London}}{{cite news |first=Sean |last=Michaels |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/may/12/michael-jackson-comeback-concerts |title=Michael Jackson comeback concerts in jeopardy? |publisher=''The Guardian'' |date=June 12, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 | location=London}} In August 2010, the judge dismissed the case, stating that there was no evidence of a binding agreement, no contracts were signed.{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-11038050 | work=BBC News | title=Judge dismisses Jackson reunion claim | date=August 20, 2010}} The case was in limbo as of 2013.{{cite web|url=http://archive.recapthelaw.org/nysd/347380/ |title=AllGood Entertainment, Inc. et al v. Jackson et al (nysd/347380) – The RECAP Archive |publisher=Archive.recapthelaw.org |date= |accessdate=May 6, 2013}}{{cite web|author=Yazmeen |url=http://muzikfactorytwo.blogspot.com/2011/05/interview-with-patrick-allocco.html |title=Interview with Patrick Allocco- President of AllGood Entertainment ~ LET'S CALL SPADE A SPADE |publisher=Muzikfactorytwo.blogspot.com |date=May 24, 2011 |accessdate=May 6, 2013}} ==Jackson's death and refunds== {{Further|Death of Michael Jackson}} On June 25, 2009, Jackson died after going into [[cardiac arrest]] which was caused by an overdose of [[Propofol]] and [[Benzodiazepine|benzodiazepines]], eighteen days before his planned first show. AEG Live, who persuaded Jackson to sign up for the shows, faced a liability of up to £300 million and an empty venue for the next nine months.{{cite news|last=Sherwin|first=Adam|title=O2 arena counts cost as curtain closes on the greatest show of all|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article6580748.ece|publisher=The Times|date=June 26, 2009|accessdate=June 26, 2009 | location=London}} The O2 arena stated that full refunds, including all ticket service charges, would be available to those who purchased tickets through authorized agents, but that "fans will have the option to be sent the actual tickets they would have received to attend the shows in lieu of the full refunds which are being offered."{{cite web |title=UCLA Statement — Michael Jackson|url=http://www.theo2.co.uk/inside/ucla-statement-michael-jackson.html |publisher=[[The O2 Arena]] |accessdate=July 1, 2009}} Fans who bought their tickets from private sellers potentially faced difficulties. eBay recommended that purchasers contact their sellers for refunds and stated that those who used PayPal can get their money back if the purchase was made during the last 45 days,{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/8120412.stm |title=Refund issues over Jackson gigs |publisher=''BBC News'' |date=June 26, 2009 |accessdate=June 26, 2009}} then later stated that "all buyers on the site will receive a full refund for their ticket purchase".{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/8122580.stm |title=eBay will refund Jackson tickets |publisher=BBC News |date=June 27, 2009 |accessdate=June 27, 2009}} ==Posthumous film and album== {{Further|Michael Jackson's This Is It|Michael Jackson's This Is It (album)}} Following Jackson's death, AEG stated that they had over "100 hours of footage of preparations and rehearsals for the shows".{{cite news |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/32360110 |title=Judge OKs Jackson performance film deal |agency=Associated Press |work=[[MSNBC|MSNBC.com]] |date=August 10, 2009 |accessdate=October 2, 2009}} On August 10, 2009, Los Angeles Superior Court Judge Mitchell Beckloff approved a deal between film distributor [[Columbia Pictures]] and AEG Live for the former company to purchase and distribute rehearsal footage of Jackson for a film entitled ''[[Michael Jackson's This Is It]]''.{{cite web |url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/showbiz/2009-08/06/content_8532737.htm |title=Michael Jackson film deal outlined in court papers |work=ChinaDaily.com |date=August 6, 2009 |accessdate=October 2, 2009}}{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-ct-jackson11-2009aug11,0,2938755.story |author=Christopher Smith |work=[[LA Times|LA Times.com]] |title=Sony Pictures to produce Michael Jackson film |accessdate=September 21, 2009 | date=August 11, 2009}} According to court documents, Columbia paid $60 million (£35 million) for rights to the rehearsal footage.{{cite web |url=http://www.uncut.co.uk/news/michael_jackson/news/13441 |title=Michael jackson This Is It film deal agreed |work=Uncut.co.uk |date=August 8, 2009|accessdate=October 3, 2009}} The papers filed in court had reportedly stated that Jackson's estate will get 90% of the profits and that AEG Live will get the remaining 10% from the film's revenue.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/aug/11/michael-jackson-film-october-release |author=Rosie Swash |title=Michael Jackson film gets October release date |work=[[Guardian.co.uk]] |date=August 11, 2009 |accessdate=October 2, 2009 | location=London}} The film was directed by [[Kenny Ortega]] who was also the director of the live concert. It was compiled mostly from footage that was shot as reference for production discussions and was never meant to be shown publicly. Some of the music and vocals in the film were added from previous recordings, though most were from the live performance. The film was released on October 28, 2009.{{cite web |url=http://www.sonypictures.com/movies/michaeljacksonthisisit/international/ |title=This Is It Worldwide Release Dates |work=[[Sony Pictures|Sony Pictures.com]] |accessdate=September 21, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090922214515/http://www.sonypictures.com/movies/michaeljacksonthisisit/international/ |archivedate=September 22, 2009 |df=mdy-all }} An accompanying album to the film was also released. Titled ''[[Michael Jackson's This Is It (album)|This Is It]]'', the compilation was distributed internationally on October 26, and to North America the following day. The two-disc album features music "inspired from the documentary of the same name".{{cite news |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/music_blog/2009/09/the-michael-jackson-new-musical-onslaught-begins.html |author=Chris Lee |title=The Michael Jackson new-music onslaught begins [Updated] |work=[[The LA Times|TheLATimes.com]] |date=September 23, 2009 |accessdate=September 24, 2009}} Of the album, Sony said, "Disc one will feature the original album masters of some of Michael's biggest hits arranged in the same sequence as they appear in the film" and stated that "the disc ends with two versions of the 'never-released' '[[This Is It (Michael Jackson song)|This Is It]]' [...] This song is featured in the film's closing sequence and includes backing vocals by Michael's brothers, [[The Jacksons]] and Alvin Chea of Take 6."{{cite web |url=http://www.digitalspy.com/music/a178845/new-jackson-single-lp-to-be-released.html?imdb |title=New Jackson single, LP to be released |author=Tim Parks |date=September 23, 2009 |work=[[Digital Spy|Digital Spy.com]] |accessdate=September 24, 2009}} Sony added that the second disc will feature previously unreleased versions from Jackson's "catalogue of hits", along with a spoken word [[poem]] entitled "Planet Earth" and a 36-page commemorative booklet with "exclusive photos of Michael from his last rehearsal".{{cite web |url=http://www.theinsider.com/news/2870440_Unreleased_Michael_Jackson_Song_to_be_Revealed|author=The Insider Staff |work=[[The Insider (TV series)|TheInsider.com]] |title=Unreleased Michael Jackson Song to be Revealed |date=September 23, 2009 |accessdate=September 23, 2009}} ==See also== * [[Death of Michael Jackson]] * [[List of works published posthumously]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.michaeljacksonlive.com/ This Is It Official Website] * [http://www.michaeljacksonlive.com/refunds.php/ Official ticket refund website] {{Michael Jackson}} {{DEFAULTSORT:This Is It (concerts)}} [[Category:2009 in London]] [[Category:2010 in London]] [[Category:Cancelled events]] [[Category:Michael Jackson concerts]]

{{Infobox book | | name = Tonto Basin | title_orig = | translator = | image = ZaneGrey TontoBasin.jpg | caption = | author = [[Zane Grey]] | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | genre = [[Western (genre)|Western novel]] | publisher = [[Thompson Gale|Five Star]] (US hardback) &
[[Leisure Books]]
(US paperback) | release_date = 1921 | media_type = Print ([[Hardback]] & [[Paperback]]) | pages = 330 p (hardback) &
321 p (paperback edition) | isbn = 978-0-8439-5602-3 |isbn_note= (paperback edition)
{{ISBN|978-1-59414-050-1}} (hardback edition) | oclc= 63177922 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} ''For the geographical place see [[Tonto Basin]] '''''Tonto Basin''''' is a western novel written by [[Zane Grey]]. ==Origin== ''Tonto Basin'' is the original version of the shorter novel ''[[To the Last Man (Zane Grey)|To The Last Man]]'' (1921). Grey submitted the manuscript of ''Tonto Basin'' to the magazine ''The Country Gentleman,'' which published it in serialization as ''To the Last Man'' from May 28, 1921 through July 30, 1921. This was a much shorter version of the original leaving out much of the [[backstory]] and [[Characterisation|character development]]. This shorter version was published as a [[book]] by [[Harper Brothers]] in 1921. ==Plot introduction== A story of a feud between two families, the evil it causes, and the power of love to transcend all. ==Plot summary== The story begins with 24-year-old Jean Isbel in the last stages of a multi-week trip from Oregon to the frontier in Arizona where his family had moved four years earlier to start a cattle ranch. As he nears his destination he meets a woman in the woods, and falls in love at first sight. As they part they learn that they are mortal enemies. She is Ellen Jorth, and her family is locked in a deadly feud with his. Jean dreads the part his father, Gaston, wants him to play in the feud. He can’t get Ellen out of his mind. They meet again and his words awake in her doubt and fear that her father, Lee Jorth, is not an honorable man but in fact a horse thief and cattle rustler. As events unfold her fears are proved true. Through thick and thin Jean Isbel defends Ellen’s honor and believes the best of her. The feud erupts into fatal gun battles, first at the Isbel ranch house, and then at the general store in the nearby town. Most of the Isbel and Jorth clans are killed, with several of their allies. The remnant of the Jorths flee with Ellen in tow to a hide-out hidden in a deep box cañon. Jean and his allies track them and there is a deadly gun battle in the woods nearby. Ellen is forced by one of the three remaining Jorth allies to flee once again. During their flight their horse is shot out from under them. Ellen now on foot meets one of the dying Isbels and finally learns the certain truth that her father, family, and their allies were horse thieves and cattle rustlers as she feared. When she finally makes her way back to the hide-out, she arrives just after Jean has been forced to take refuge in the loft, unknown to her. One of the two remaining rustlers attacks her with rape in mind but is interrupted by the arrival of the other rustler. Ellen discovers Jean during this interruption. When the rustler returns a few minutes later, Ellen is forced to kill him to protect herself and Jean. A minute later Jean kills the last rustler. The story ends with Jean and Ellen declaring their love for each other. ==Themes== The book is concerned with the destruction deadly violence wreaks on those family members who survive. Grey writes about the intense concern Jean feels for the impact the violence will have on the wives and children whose husbands and fathers will die in the feud. The feud is caused by a love triangle between Gaston Isbel, Lee Jorth, and Ellen the woman both love, and the mother of Ellen Jorth. The story explores how love, betrayal, and jealousy can engender a hate which leads two men to destroy their families, without a thought to the pain and suffering of those relatives who will be left to bury the dead. Ellen grows from a naïve girl to a woman of understanding under the severe trial of the events which overtake her. She begins to examine critically her own behavior with wisdom and insight. She grows and matures emotionally and psychologically, becoming aware that her father whom she had supported with unquestioning trust, is in fact a scoundrel, a thief, and a thoroughly dishonorable rogue. At the end she acts decisively and fatally to protect herself, her virtue, and the man she loves. ==Characters in "To the Last Man"== * Jean Isbel – the hero, a person of mixed race, being part [[Nez Perce tribe|Nez Perce]] * Gaston Isbel – Jean's father, and the head of the Isbel faction. * Guy Isble – Jean's oldest brother. * Bill Isble – Jean's older brother. * Ann Isble – Jean's sister. * Andrew Colmor – Ann's fiancé. * Jim Blaisdell – Gaston's good friend and supporter. * Blue – member of the Isbel faction. * Lee Jorth – the head of the Jorth faction. * Ellen Jorth – Lee's daughter. * Tad Jorth – Lee's brother, Ellen's uncle. * Jackson Jorth – Lee's brother, Ellen's uncle. * Jim Colter – member of the Jorth faction. * Springer – member of the Jorth faction. * Sommers – member of the Jorth faction. * Rock Wells – member of the Jorth faction. * Colter – member of the Jorth faction. * Simm Bruce – member of the Jorth faction. * Ben Greaves – owner of the General Store. * John Sprague – Ellen's confidante and only friend. ==Publication== In the early 1990s, [[Jon Tuska]], was researching the [[filmography]] of Zane Grey. During this research he discovered that ''[[Last of the Duanes (novel)|Last of the Duanes]]'' and ''[[Rangers of the Lone Star]]'' were much altered from the [[holograph]] found "in the bottom drawer of a file cabinet in the Zane Grey, Inc. room where it had survived for eighty years.".Grey, Zane: "Tonto Basin", (quote from the ''Foreword'' by Jon Tuska) page 8. Five Star, 2004. {{ISBN|978-1-59414-050-1}} This caused him to request that they "tell me of any other manuscripts...that had met a similar fate."Grey, Zane: "Tonto Basin", (quote from the ''Foreword'' by Jon Tuska) page 9. Five Star, 2004. {{ISBN|978-1-59414-050-1}} The result was the discovery of the complete holographic [[manuscript]] of the novel ''[[To the Last Man (Zane Grey)|To the Last Man]]''. A comparison of the holograph with ''To the Last Man'' revealed that the holograph was much longer, and contained detail which altered the meaning of the story. The complete uncut version was published in 2004. ==See also== {{portal|Novels}} *''[[To the Last Man (1933 film)|To the Last Man]]'' is a 1933 [[Henry Hathaway]] film based on the [[Zane Grey]] novel starring [[Randolph Scott]], [[Esther Ralston]], [[Buster Crabbe]], [[Barton MacLane]], [[Noah Beery]], [[Shirley Temple]], and [[Eugenie Besserer]]. * [[Frederick Russell Burnham]] participated on the losing side in the real-life [[Pleasant Valley War|Tonto Basin feud]] and narrowly escaped alive. After the feud, he went home to [[California]] and left for [[Africa]] only a few years later.{{cite book | last =Burnham | first =Frederick Russell | authorlink =Frederick Russell Burnham | coauthors = | title =Scouting on Two Continents | publisher =Doubleday, Page and Co | year =1926 | location = New York | pages = Chapters 3 & 4| url = | doi = | id = ASIN B000F1UKOA }}{{cite journal| author =R. R. Money|date=April 1962 | title=Tonto Basin Feud | journal=[[Blackwood's Magazine]]| volume=291| issue=| issn=0006-436X }} * Tonto Basin Outlaws (1941) - A film based very loosely on the Tonto Basin feud. These cowboys are out to stop a cattle-rustling scandal soon after they enlist with [[Teddy Roosevelt]]'s [[Rough Riders]].{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0034300/ |title=Tonto Basin Outlaws (1941)|accessdate=2007-07-07 |work=Internet Movie Database}} In the real-life feud, one man did go on to join the Rough Riders. * [[Pleasant Valley War]] ==Footnotes== {{Reflist}} [[Category:1921 American novels]] [[Category:Western (genre) novels]] [[Category:Novels by Zane Grey]] [[Category:Novels set in Arizona]] [[Category:Works based on actual events]]

{{external links|date=July 2015}} The term '''use error''' has recently been introduced to replace the commonly used terms '''[[human error]]''' and '''[[user error]]'''. The new term, which has already been adopted by [[international standard]]s organizations for [[medical device]]s (see [[#Use errors in health care]] below for references), suggests that [[accident]]s should be attributed to the circumstances, rather than to the human beings who happened to be there.
==The need for the terminological change== The term "use error" was first used in May 1995 in an [[MD+DI]] guest editorial, [http://www.mddionline.com/article/issue-use-not-user-error “The Issue Is ‘Use,’ Not ‘User,’ Error,”] by [http://biomed.tamu.edu/people/faculty.php?lname=Hyman William Hyman].<ref>http://www.mddionline.com/article/issue-use-not-user-error</ref> Traditionally, human errors are considered as a special aspect of [[human factors]]. Accordingly, they are attributed to the human [[Computer operator|operator]], or [[user (computing)|user]]. When taking this approach, we assume that the system design is perfect, and the only source for the use errors is the human operator. For example, the [[U.S. Department of Defense]] (DoD) [[HFACS]] <ref>[http://uscg.mil/careercentral/cg113/docs/ergo_hfacs/hfacs.pdf], Department of Defense Human Factors Analysis and Classification System: A mishap investigation and data analysis tool</ref> classifies use errors attributed to the human operator, disregarding improper design and configuration setting, which often result in missing [[alarms]], or in inappropriate [[alert messaging|alerting]].
The need for changing the term was due to a common [[malpractice]] of the [[Project stakeholder|stakeholder]]s (the responsible organizations, the authorities, journalists) in cases of accidents.<ref>[http://www.lu.se/upload/Trafikflyghogskolan/TR2002-01_ReInventionofHumanError.pdf], Dekker: Reinvention of Human Error</ref> Instead of investing in fixing the error-prone design, management attributed the error to the users. The need for the change has been pointed out by the accident investigators: * Early in 1983, Erik Hollnagel<ref> [https://sites.google.com/site/erikhollnagel2/], Erik Hollnagel home page </ref> pointed out that the term Human Error refers to the outcome, not to the cause. A user action is typically classified as an error only if the results are painful <ref>[http://www.ida.liu.se/~eriho/Bellagio_M.htm], Hollnagel: Why "Human Error" is a Meaningless Concept</ref> * In the story “Leap of Faith” of his book “Set Phasers on Stun”,<ref>[http://www.aegeanpublishing.com/phaser1.html], Steve Casey: Set Phasers on Stun</ref> Steve Casey suggested that the accident of the [[Indian Airlines Flight 605]] near Bangalor in 1990 could have been avoided, should the investigators of the [[Air France Flight 296]] accident of 1988 past the Mulhouse-Habsheim airport considered the circumstances (exceptional situation), rather than the pilots (human errors). * In his book “Managing the Risks of Organizational Accidents” ([[Organizational models of accidents]]) James Reason explained and demonstrated that often, the circumstances for accidents could have been controlled by the responsible organization, and not by the operators. * In his book “The Field Guide to Understanding Human Errors”,<ref>[http://www.ashgate.com/isbn/9780754648260], Sidney Dekker: The Field Guide to Understanding Human Error</ref> Sidney Dekker argued that blaming the operators according to “The Old View” results in defensive behavior of operators, which hampers the efforts to learn from near-misses and from accidents.
==Use errors vs. force majeure== A mishap is typically considered as either a use error or a force majeure: <ref name="Weiler">[http://avi.har-el.com/eng/Articles/ITS-Alarms-Apr2011.pdf], Weiler and Harel: Managing the Risks of Use Errors: The ITS Warning Systems Case Study</ref> * A use error is a mishap in which a human operator is involved. Typically, such mishaps are attributed to the failure of the human operator <ref> [http://www.ashgate.com/isbn/9780754648260], Dekker, 2007: The Field Guide to Understanding Human Error </ref> * A force majeure is a mishap that does not involve a human being in the chain of events preceding the event.
==Use errors in health care== In 1998, Cook, Woods and Miller presented the concept of [[hindsight bias]], exemplified by celebrated accidents in medicine, by a workgroup on patient safety .<ref> [http://www.ctlab.org/documents/A%20Tale%20of%20Two%20Stories.pdf], Cook RI, Woods DD, Miller C [1998] A Tale of Two Stories: Contrasting Views of Patient Safety </ref> The workgroup pointed at the tendency to attribute accidents in health care to isolated human failures. They provide references to early research about the effect of knowledge of the outcome, which was unavailable beforehand, on later judgement about the processes that led up to that outcome. They explain that in looking back, we tend to oversimplify the situation that the actual practitioners faces. They conclude focusing on the hindsight knowledge prevents our understanding of the richer story, the circumstances of the human error.
According to this position, the term Use Error is formally defined in several [[international standard]]s, such as [[International Electrotechnical Commission|IEC]] 62366, [[ISO 14155]] and [[ISO 14971]], to describe : ''an act or omission of an act that results in a different medical device response than intended by the manufacturer or expected by the user.''
[[ISO standards]] about medical devices and procedures provide examples of use errors, which are attributed to human factors, include slips, [[lapses]] and mistakes. Practically, this means that they are attributed to the user, implying the user’s accountability. The U.S. [[Food and Drug Administration]] glossary of medical devices provides the following explanation about this term:<ref>[http://www.fda.gov/MedicalDevices/ProductsandMedicalProcedures/GeneralHospitalDevicesandSupplies/InfusionPumps/ucm202502.htm], FDA, Medical Devices, Glossary</ref>
:"Safe and effective use of a medical device means that users do not make errors that lead to injury and they achieve the desired medical treatment. If safe and effective use is not achieved, use error has occurred. Why and how use error occurs is a [[human factors]] concern."
With this interpretation by ISO and the FDA, the term ‘use error’ is actually synonymous with ‘user error’. Another approach, which distinguishes ‘use errors’ from ‘user errors', is taken by IEC 62366. Annex A includes an explanation justifying the new term: :"This International Standard uses the concept of use error. This term was chosen over the more commonly used term of “human error” because not all errors associated with the use of medical device are the result of oversight or carelessness of the part of the user of the medical device. Much more commonly, use errors are the direct result of poor user interface design."
This explanation complies with “The New View”, which Sidney Dekker suggested as an alternative to “The Old View”. This interpretation favors investigations intended to understand the situation, rather than blaming the operators.
In a 2011 report draft on health IT usability, the U.S. [[National Institute of Standards and Technology]] (NIST) defines "use error" in healthcare IT this way: “Use error is a term used very specifically to refer to user interface designs that will engender users to make errors of commission or omission. It is true that users do make errors, but many errors are due not to user error per se but due to designs that are flawed, e.g., poorly written messaging, misuse of color-coding conventions, omission of information, etc.".<ref>''NISTIR 7804: Technical Evaluation, Testing and Validation of the Usability of Electronic Health Records, Draft, Sept. 2011, pg. 10. '' [https://www.nist.gov/healthcare/usability/upload/Draft_EUP_09_28_11.pdf]</ref>
=== Example of user error === An example of an accident due to a user error is the ecological disaster of 1967 caused by the [[Torrey Canyon]] supertanker. The accident was due to a combination of several exceptional events, the result of which was that the supertanker was heading directly to the rocks. At that point, the captain failed to change the course because the steering control lever was inadvertently set to the Control position, which disconnected the rudder from the wheel at the helm.<ref>Steve Casey, A memento of your service, in Set Phasers on Stun, 1998</ref>
===Examples of user failure to handle system failure=== Examples of the second type are the [[Three Mile Island accident]] described above, the [[New York City blackout of 1977|NYC blackout]] following a storm and the chemical plant disaster in Bhopal, India ([[Bhopal Disaster]]).
==Classifying use errors== The URM Model <ref name="Task-oriented"> [http://avi.har-el.com/eng/Articles/Task-Oriented-SE.pdf], Zonnenshain & Harel: Task-oriented SE, INCOSE 2009 Conference, Singapore</ref> characterizes use errors in terms of the user’s failure to manage a system deficiency. Six categories of use errors are described in a URM document: #Expected faults with risky results; #Expected faults with unexpected results; #Expected user errors in identifying risky situations (this study); #User Errors in handling expected faults; #Expected errors in function selection; #Unexpected faults, due to operating in exceptional states.
==Critics== Erik Hollnagel argues that going from and 'old' view to a 'new' view is not enough. One should go all the way to a 'no' view. This means that the notion of error, whether user error or use error might be destructive rather than constructive. Instead, he proposes to focus on the performance variability of everyday actions, on the basis that this performance variability is both useful and necessary. In most cases the result is that things go right, in a few cases that things go wrong. But the reason is the same. <ref> [http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/freeabs_all.jsp?arnumber=1042821] Hollnagel: Understanding accidents-from root causes to performance variability </ref> Hollnagel expanded on this in his writings about the [[efficiency–thoroughness trade-off principle]] <ref> [http://functionalresonance.com/ETTO_Introduction.html], The ETTO Principle – Efficiency-Thoroughness Trade-Off </ref> of Resilience Engineering, <ref> [http://www.ashgate.com/isbn/9781409410355] Hollnagel, Paries, Woods, Wreathall (editors): Resilience engineering in practice </ref> and the Resilient Health Care Net. <ref> [http://www.resilienthealthcare.net] the Resilient Health Care Net </ref>

{{Infobox book | name = When Technology Fails | image = When Technology Fails.jpg<!-- include the [[File:]] and the image size --> | caption = | author = [[Neil Y. Schlager]] (ed.) | country = United States | language = English | subject = Reference | publisher = [[Gale (publisher)|Gale Research]] | pub_date = January 1994 | pages = 659 | isbn = 978-0-8103-8908-3 | oclc = 29315606 | dewey = 363.1 W574 }} '''''When Technology Fails''''', edited by [[Neil Schlager]], is a collection of 103 [[case study|case studies]] about significant technological disasters, accidents, and failures of the 20th century.<ref>{{cite book|title=Minding the Machines: Preventing Technological Disasters|last1=Evan|first1=William M.|last2=Manion|first2=Mark|isbn=0-13-065646-1|year=2002|publisher=[[Prentice Hall]] PTR|location=Upper Saddle River, New Jersey|page=203}}</ref> It was published in 1994 by [[Gale (publisher)|Gale Research, Inc.]] It was one of the top referenced books in the [[New York Public Library]] in 1995.<ref>{{cite news|last=Miller|first=Melinda|newspaper=Buffalo News|location=Buffalo, NY|date=November 5, 1995|title=Stranger Than Fiction: The Libraries' Tops in Reference|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=BN&p_theme=bn&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EAF98E2DDC999D0&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|accessdate=2011-04-14}} {{subscription required}}</ref> The book was updated and re-released in 2005.
The book consists of 1,000- to 1,500-word entries, arranged by subject, that discuss the background, timeline, and impact of each event.<ref>Accari, Joe. Book Review. ''Library Journal'', [[Northeastern Illinois University]] Library, [[Chicago, Illinois]]. 1994. [http://www.syndetics.com/index.aspx?isbn=9780810389083/LJREVIEW.HTML&client=newportp]. Accessed 2011-04-14.</ref> Each entry is written by journalists, engineers, and researchers, and provides a cursory overview, rather than in-depth technological analysis.<ref>"Choice," [[American Library Association]]. Book Review. [http://readon.sg/det_6859750.aspx] Accessed 2011-04-14.</ref> Entries are supplemented by [[bibliography|bibliographies]], black-and-white photographs, charts, and other print media.<ref>Book Review. ''[[Booklist]],'' American Library Association. [http://www.booklistonline.com/]. Accessed 2011-04-14.</ref>
